Quick Facts

EXIT   X

WORKERS' RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS

Page

Table of Contents

 

 

Do you remember the scenario?

 

 

Which answer is true about Mike’s conduct?

Scenario

 

Rosie is a secretary at Publishing Co. Rosie has been directed to shred some business documents. When she goes to do this, Rosie notices that the safety guard on the shredder is missing. Rosie decides to stop working. She tells Mike, her manager, that she will not work on the shredder until the guard is replaced.

 

Mike is not impressed with her concerns. He informs her that, by law, she is not allowed to cease work. Mike knows this is not true, but they’re trying to meet a tight deadline and the last thing he needs is a member of staff causing a fuss.

 

Rosie feels that Mike is trying to intimidate her to go back and use the faulty equipment.

Mike is being realistic – missing the deadline poses a far greater risk to the continuation of the business

Mike is making a prohibited misrepresentation by saying Rosie is not allowed to stop working

Mike is within his rights as a supervisor to overrule Rosie’s concerns and demand she goes back to work

 
 
 

That is incorrect

 

No person may knowingly or recklessly mislead another person about their legal ability to cease work.

That is correct!

 

No person may knowingly or recklessly mislead another person about their legal ability to cease work.

That is incorrect

 

No person may knowingly or recklessly mislead another person about their legal ability to cease work.
